results.title: Mathematics for modern living
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Associates and ACCESS
results.brief_description: This series of instructional tapes aimed at lower to middle level secondary students covers the mathematical areas of probability, linear equations, counting techniques, graphing and variables.

results.title: Coordinate graphing 2
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Associates and ACCESS
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematics for modern living”.
This episode from the “Mathematics for modern living” series teaches the basics of graphing including the slope of the line, oblique, horizontal and vertical, then progresses onto graphing linear equations (slope intercept method), two firstdegree linear equations and graphing linear inequations. Suitable for lower to middle secondary level students. A study guide accompanies this tape.

results.title: Probability 2
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Associates and ACCESS
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematics for modern living”.
This episode from the “Mathematics for modern living” series is a continuation of “Probability 1” (see 309029) and covers the areas of; formulas for finding permutations of n, probability of two mutually exclusive events and two independent events. Suitable for lower to middle secondary level students. A study guide accompanies this tape.

results.title: Probability 1 : counting techniques
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Associates and ACCESS
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematics for modern living”.
This episode from the “Mathematics for modern living” series introduces the concepts of chance and probability through examples of everyday life. It discusses games of chance and everyday space, closely followed by counting techniques. Suitable for lower to middle secondary level students. A study guide accompanies this tape.

results.title: Problem of acceptance
results.brief_description: A condensation of the therapy session held with patients of the psychiatric ward of the University of Oregon Medical School. The theme is a psychodramtic exploration of a 17 year old girl’s attempt to deal with her homosexuality.

results.title: Problem clinic
results.creator_credit: Ronald Weyman, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Few people, faced with the complicated machinery of the law, know how to proceed without legal counsel or defence. Yet many are unable to pay for the services of a lawyer. The Law Societies of many of the provinces, encouraged by the Canadian Bar Association, extend help in the form of free legal-aid clinics staffed by volunteer lawyers. Enacted here is a case in which a young man facing a criminal charge is defended by a legal-aid lawyer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ronald Weyman, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Prisoner: the end [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Marie Trevor and Reg Grundy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Prisoner [Cell block H]”.
Ep. 600 (dir. Steve Mann, wri. Ian Smith): Top Dog Lou Kelly (Louise Siversen) takes control of the prison and unleashes a reign of bashings, execution and intimidation. The episode culminates in an orchestrated fight to the death between The Freak (Maggie Kirkpatrick) and Rita Connors (Glenda Linscott). “Ep. 601” (dir. Kendal Flanagan, wri. Alister Webb): The siege is over and there are repercussions for ringleader Lou. Will anyone break the prisoners code of silence? The search is on for a new Top Dog. “Ep. 691” (dir. Sean Nash, wri. Quincy McQuade): Concludes the storyline of the relationship between supporting characters Kath and Merle. Rumours spread of Rita’s cancer as well as concern at her purported friendship with The Freak. “Ep. 692” (dir. Sean Nash, wri. Marie Trevor, Ian Smith): In the climatic final episode Rita carries out the robbery planned in collaboration with The Freak. Retrieving the money appears hard though as Rita is captured and placed under close observation. Each section of episodes are introduced by Peter McTighe who explains what has transpired in the missing instalments. PLEASE NOTE: date recorded is copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.
